remarks.para: This method parses looking for FUSE-formatted arguments. A FUSE-formatted argument is one of:

item.term: -d to enable FUSE debug output. This is also equivalent to -odebug.
-f to enable foreground output. This is the only permitted behavior anyway, so it's simply ignored.
-s to disable multithreading support within FUSE. By default multithreading is . (See also .)
Any argument of the form -ostring, -ostring=value, and the argument pairs -o string, -o string=value. argument or argument pair matching this pattern will be handled by ParseFuseArguments.

block.para: If any non-FUSE arguments are captured by this method, they will be stored in and provided to FUSE during the method. If any non-FUSE arguments are passed to FUSE, FUSE will report an error.

paramref.name: Do not pass non-FUSE arguments to FUSE.

Docs.param: A containing the program name to display within the help text.
Docs.summary: Writes FUSE argument information to your programs standard error stream.

remarks.para: Use this method to show the FUSE arguments within your help information.

example.para: should be used to augment your help text generation when handling the standard --help argument.
The above program generates the output:
example.code:
usage: helpfs mountpoint [options]
general options: -o opt,[opt...] mount options -h --help print help -V --version print version
FUSE options: -d -o debug enable debug output (implies -f) -f foreground operation -s disable multi-threaded operation
-o allow_other allow access to other users -o allow_root allow access to root -o nonempty allow mounts over non-empty file/dir -o default_permissions enable permission checking by kernel -o fsname=NAME set filesystem name -o large_read issue large read requests (2.4 only) -o max_read=N set maximum size of read requests
-o hard_remove immediate removal (don't hide files) -o use_ino let filesystem set inode numbers -o readdir_ino try to fill in d_ino in readdir -o direct_io use direct I/O -o kernel_cache cache files in kernel -o umask=M set file permissions (octal) -o uid=N set file owner -o gid=N set file group -o entry_timeout=T cache timeout for names (1.0s) -o negative_timeout=T cache timeout for deleted names (0.0s) -o attr_timeout=T cache timeout for attributes (1.0s)
helpfs options: --argument-name-here Summary Information

is called on each of a file descriptor. So if a file system wants to return write errors in close(2) and and the file has cached dirty data, this is a good place to write back data and return any errors. Since many applications ignore close(2) errors this is not always useful.

File systems shouldn't assume that will always be called after some writes, or that it will be called at all.
